content.text: A **definition** is a rule of paraphrase intended to explain meaning. It tells us how to replace one word or phrase with another that means the same thing.

content.definition: A definition that explains the current, commonly accepted usage of a word. It describes how people actually use the term.

content.title: A Correct Lexical Definition
premises: We can interchange these in sentences:
content.conclusion: 'Al is a bachelor' = 'Al is an unmarried man'
content.note: These mean the same thing, so the definition is correct.

content.definition: To test a lexical definition claiming A means B: try switching A and B in various sentences. If any resulting pair doesn't mean the same thing, the definition is incorrect.

content.title: An Incorrect Definition
premises: Testing: 'Al is a bachelor' vs 'Al is a happy man'
content.conclusion: These don't mean the same thing - Al could be an unhappy bachelor!
content.note: The definition fails the interchange test and is therefore incorrect.

symbols.name: Not too broad/narrow
symbols.meaning: Must cover exactly the right cases

symbols.name: Avoid circularity
symbols.meaning: Don't use the word in its own definition

symbols.name: Match vagueness
symbols.meaning: Don't be more precise than the original

symbols.name: Match emotional tone
symbols.meaning: Keep neutral if original is neutral

symbols.name: Essential properties only
symbols.meaning: Include only what's necessary to the meaning

content.question: What's wrong with defining 'game' as 'competition between two parties with winning and losing'?
options: It's too broad (includes wars) and too narrow (excludes solitaire)
It has the wrong emotional tone
content.explanation: This definition is both too broad (a military battle would count as a 'game') and too narrow (solitaire is a game but has no competitor). A good definition must cover exactly the right cases.
